title: Bringing dark pools to Hyperliquid with Silhouette

cleanText:
Head to the bot.co/campus to get a three-month free trial. Now, today's episode is about dark pools on Hyperliquid, a fairly new development, something that Silhouette is hoping to bring out. So, can you sort of explain what is Silhouette and what are dark pools?

Cool. Dark pools is a concept that comes from traditional finance. Typically, how you know trading happens in the traditional finance world is you've got your stock exchanges, the New York Stock Exchange, the London Stock Exchange, and these are really good anchoring points for price discovery and for the market to coordinate around. Now, they use different mechanisms in different types of markets, but most of the time they look like central order limit books, much to what you can see in Coinbase and Kraken. Now, today Hyperliquid and these types of trading mechanisms are really, really good for you to enter and exit markets for most of the use cases. One of the other interesting developments that happened when you kind of coordinate your trading on these mechanisms is that if everyone were to kind of do their trades on these mechanisms, you would end up kind of slipping the market if you were to trade in size or you wanted to trade kind of OTC or do a different use a different mechanism. One way, particularly, that you would do it off-book. This is where kind of these dark pools emerged in finance. Now, dark pools in finance is just simply one firm trading with another firm, and that trade would not necessarily be disclosed in any way, shape, or form. So, the details of the trade would not necessarily be open and transparent, and this gave kind of just like another venue for traders to trade. And one of the key features there was the privacy that it enabled. This is really an important development because in markets where price discovery and typically in traditional market price discovery was quite easy to find because you know the reporting standards made price discovery a concept that was fairly simple to for most traders to get access to. These dark pools actually enhance the ability for more traders to trade. And so what we noticed is that you know in with the additional privacy being added to these traditional markets, we basically had more trade happen as a net result. You basically just need an RPC provider and you can read the state from any sort of chain kind of at a very, very cheap at very, very low costs. Trusted execution environments have been around for ages. These are you know your your fingerprint scanner on your MacBook Pro that uses a secure enclave to kind of keep data protected within a larger computer. So you can kind of think of it as this like protected computer within a larger computer. In addition to that, like so that's where we can kind of run a lot of these like matching components to provide the privacy that we need, but then there is this other component that really kind of a lot of the ZK side of the world, FH, and MPC type technology stacks really come into play, so we can generate a proof from this trusted execution environment to tie into like the onchain settlement. So from like a buildout perspective, Silhouette's you know three components. Traders submit their order. That's the one component to Silhouette. We use these secure enclaves to privately match trades and order flow. And then the last component is settlement where we use ZK to ultimately settle onchain. And in this in our specific case for our first kind of like rollout of our product, that'll kind of go into the Hyperliquid ecosystem.

You could also run it in one of these enclaves, which gives you a little bit more security guarantees around what the actual matching engine is doing.

Okay. So So is it decentralized?

The decentraliz so what in in the world of decentralization, what does decentralization mean? It's like how many people can run the node that ultimately gets consensus? Now in Ethereum, I can spin up my node at home. I need 32 ETH, can kind of get that set up fairly, fairly simply, and now I'm part of this decentralized network. In some other chains, there's far less nodes, and that kind of you could assume it's less decentralized. There's like Nakamoto coefficient is a good example of how decentralized a network is. And for our case, the way that you would kind of introduce decentralization is by having multiple of these execution environments running together. So if one went down, the network as a whole would not necessarily break down. So decentralization also is quite an important path that many teams kind of overindex on in the beginning that leads to some sort of stifling in the future. So we have a path to decentralization. That path will be kind of taken a little bit more cautiously from our perspective. So we'll have like a small subnet of these trusted execution environments running in the beginning. We'll figure out that you know is this product something that we know where does this product fit within the market and you know what are the key features that we would want to enable that users would use, and once that kind of starts generating a decent amount of value, the concept of decentralization then becomes a little bit easier for us to rationalize around. So you know we're starting very centralized in the beginning with a few execution environments and then slowly like increasing that over time when the value is kind of makes sense for these networks to actually become decentralized.

Okay. And then how let's say if you have other people setting up these trust execution environments, how do you know that what they're doing is according to the specific rules that you want to be in place? And then also how do people know that your environment is subject to those rules?

Yeah, this is actually a key to why we chose execution environment. So the one so one of the so we achieved this by kind of like working through a couple there's a couple layers to this. The first layer that kind of makes what the guarantees of what you're running within these execution environments is that even if I'm the I'm running the software. So Tim, you running one of our trusted execution environments, you can't access what's happening on the inside of that enclave. So even if you own the hardware and run the hardware and then kind of like want to tamper with the system, we you can't do that. So these these are why these enclaves are super secure and the the access to them is very, very tightly controlled. The only thing that you can really do is just simply turn your system off. And now you're no longer part of the network. So that's kind of one of the areas that we're we're kind of working with some of these TE providers to kind of add some robustness there. The second one is well like you know the code that runs inside of those execution environments can be open source. So we can say this is what the matching engine's going to do. We publish the code. We write the documentation around that. And then within the enclave, you can generate an execution proof that the you can see what the code is going to do. It did what it did. And then you can generate a proof that that actually was executed correctly. And that's part of the way the settlement proofs that go onchain come from. And so not only can we make sure that like you know access to these execution environments is somewhat gated, we can also make sure that the code that's running within them is super secure and then we can even create proof to show the user, oh at the end of the day what you said it should do, it actually did and here's the verification of that.

Yeah. Okay. So if someone else sets up uh one of these environments, they don't build it themselves. You would give them the secure enclave. Is that right?

All right. And then so why did you choose Hyperliquid as a base for this platform? Like why did you choose to build on it?

Yeah. So going back, you know, every time a new cryptographic paradigm came out prior to, you know, what we have today, the first thing developers developed was a dark pool. You know, ZK, they built ZK dark pools. FE, they built an FG dark pool. MPC, you name it. There's there's hundreds of these implementations of how you can build privacy trading mechanisms. And by and large, most of them have failed for a couple reasons. One of them is that they typically like have low liquidity and you know liquidity normally kind of has alpha attached to it and the privacy is there to protect the alpha and so there's no liquidity there's no alpha and so traders typically haven't really just like bootstrapped these markets relatively efficiently because privacy in itself doesn't sell. Privacy sells only in the pursuit of protecting alpha and so when we were looking at how we could implement our version of this, it was really more a go-to-market question as opposed to a technical question. And when you looked at how liquidity typically flowed, Hyperliquid was kind of growing as this nexus point for a large amount of traders. You know, pre their TGE, it was somewhat like known by a couple traders, but not really as on the map as it is today. And so they grew a community quite organically. They they also developed pretty much the the standard of how dexes will be deployed going forward. And when we looked at kind of a venue for where we could tie these dark pools into, it was very clear to us that we needed to tie into a really sufficiently kind of robust ecosystem. And that's where Hyperliquid came in. And so for us the the choice was more a case of we we knew that just privacy but for privacy's sake was not going to be enough of a sufficient set of tools for traders to come organically to an isolated market. But instead bringing privacy to where a lot of alpha is already being generated by a lot of these traders that are trading organically. And so therefore, like it made sense to build alongside a liquid venue as opposed to just simply an isolated privacy deck.
